metadata.titleEn: Dataset of ground truth land surface evapotranspiration at the satellite pixel scale in the Heihe River Basin (from multi-station observations to satellite pixel scale) Version 1.0
metadata.description:
Surface evapotranspiration (ET) is an important link of water cycle and energy transmission in the earth system. The accurate acquisition of ET is helpful to the study of global climate change, crop yield estimation, drought monitoring, and has important guiding significance for regional and even global water resources planning and management. With the development of remote sensing technology, remote sensing estimation of surface evapotranspiration has become an effective way to obtain regional and global evapotranspiration. At present, a variety of low and medium resolution surface evapotranspiration products have been produced and released in business. However, there are still many uncertainties in the model mechanism, input data, parameterization scheme of remote sensing estimation of surface evapotranspiration model. Therefore, it is necessary to use the real method. The accuracy of remote sensing estimation of evapotranspiration products was quantitatively evaluated by sex test. However, in the process of authenticity test, there is a problem of spatial scale mismatch between the remote sensing estimation value of surface evapotranspiration and the site observation value, so the key is to obtain the relative truth value of satellite pixel scale surface evapotranspiration.

Based on the flux observation matrix of "multi-scale observation experiment of non-uniform underlying surface evaporation" in the middle reaches of Heihe River Basin from June to September 2012, the stations 4 (Village), 5 (corn), 6 (corn), 7 (corn), 8 (corn), 11 (corn), 12 (corn), 13 (corn), 14 (corn), 15 (corn), 17 (orchard) and the lower reaches of January to December 2014 Oasis Populus euphratica forest station (Populus euphratica forest), mixed forest station (Tamarix / Populus euphratica), bare land station (bare land), farmland station (melon), sidaoqiao station (Tamarix) observation data (automatic meteorological station, eddy correlator, large aperture scintillation meter, etc.) are used as auxiliary data, and the high-resolution remote sensing data (surface temperature, vegetation index, net radiation, etc.) are used as auxiliary data. See Fig. 1 for the distribution map. Considering the land Through direct test and cross test, six scale expansion methods (area weight method, scale expansion method based on Priestley Taylor formula, unequal weight surface to surface regression Kriging method, artificial neural network, random forest, depth belief network) were compared and analyzed, and finally a comprehensive method (on the underlying surface) was optimized. The area weight method is used when the underlying surface is moderately inhomogeneous; the unequal weight surface to surface regression Kriging method is used when the underlying surface is moderately inhomogeneous; the random forest method is used when the underlying surface is highly inhomogeneous) to obtain the relative true value (spatial resolution of 1km) of the surface evapotranspiration pixel scale of MODIS satellite transit instantaneous / day in the middle and lower reaches of the flux observation matrix area respectively, and to observe through the scintillation with large aperture. The results show that the overall accuracy of the data set is good. The average absolute percentage error (MAPE) of the pixel scale relative truth instantaneous and day-to-day is 2.6% and 4.5% for the midstream satellite, and 9.7% and 12.7% for the downstream satellite, respectively. It can be used to verify other remote sensing products. The evapotranspiration data of the pixel can not only solve the problem of spatial mismatch between the remote sensing estimation value and the station observation value, but also represent the uncertainty of the verification process. For all site information and scale expansion methods, please refer to Li et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2016), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2016).

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Land surface evapotranspiration (ET) is an important component of the surface energy budget and water cycle. To solve the problem of the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ observations and remotely sensed ET, it is necessary to find the most appropriate upscaling approach for acquiring ground truth ET data at the satellite pixel scale.
research objective: In summary, this study was based on two matrices data from the HiWATER experiment: the MUSOEXE conducted in the middle stream of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) from May to September in 2012 and the Hydrometeorological Observation Network conducted in the downstream of the HRB from 2013 to 2015. Although there are many upscaling methods, most upscaling methods currently developed for ET are in the exploratory stage. Due to the heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces and the complexity of near-surface meteorological conditions, the applicability of different upscaling methods varies, and each method has cons and pros. Therefore, carrying out a comparative study of various upscaling methods is necessary in order to determine the most appropriate upscaling method over heterogeneous surfaces to obtain ground truth ET data at the satellite pixel scale and to reduce uncertainty due to spatial-scale mismatch in the validation process.
challenges: A major problem is the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and RS_ET products. Therefore, it is important to select appropriate validation pixels. Although the problem of spatial-scale mismatch can be partially addressed, the heterogeneity of the subpixel will have a greater impact on the results of the validation. The applicability of different upscaling methods varies, and each method has cons and pros.
methods: Based on a data set from two flux observation matrices in the middle stream and downstream of the Heihe River Basin, six upscaling methods were intercompared via direct validation and cross validation.
dataset: Based on a data set from two flux observation matrices in the middle stream and downstream of the Heihe River Basin.
findings: The results showed that the area-weighted method performed better than the other five upscaling methods introducing auxiliary variables (the integrated Priestley-Taylor equation, weighted area-to-area regression kriging [WATARK], artificial neural network, random forest [RF], and deep belief network methods) over homogeneous underlying surfaces. Over moderately heterogeneous underlying surfaces, the WATARK method performed better. However, the RF method performed better over highly heterogeneous underlying surfaces.

Verification.Question: Can the area-weighted method effectively address the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remotely sensed evapotranspiration data over homogeneous surfaces?
Is the random forest method suitable for upscaling evapotranspiration data over highly heterogeneous surfaces?
Does the data collection method in the Heihe River Basin involve the use of large aperture scintillometers and eddy covariance towers?

Disjunctive.Question: Which upscaling method is more suitable for homogeneous underlying surfaces when acquiring ET data at the satellite pixel scale: area-weighted method, WATARK, or random forest?
For highly heterogeneous underlying surfaces, which method is more effective for upscaling ET: random forest, area-weighted method, or deep belief network?

Concept Completion.Answer: flux observation matrices, eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, L-band microwave radiometer

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to address the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remotely sensed evapotranspiration (ET) data?
Example.Answer: One example involves the use of a flux observation matrix that includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This method captures multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and helps address the spatial-scale mismatch by using high-resolution airborne remote sensing data and synchronical ground measurements.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a challenge faced when collecting data on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous surfaces.
Example.Answer: A major challenge is the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remote sensing ET products. The heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces and the complexity of near-surface meteorological conditions can impact validation results, requiring careful selection of appropriate validation pixels and upscaling methods.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that provides multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area?
Example.Answer: A dataset from the HiWATER experiment provides multiscale observations by utilizing a flux observation matrix, an eco-hydrological sensor network, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing. This dataset includes data on soil moisture, leaf area index, and vegetation dynamics, which are freely available at data centers like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Feature Specification.Answer: underlying surface heterogeneity, meteorological conditions, area-weighted method, integrated Priestley-Taylor equation, weighted area-to-area regression kriging, artificial neural network, random forest, deep belief network methods

Definition.Question: What does 'upscaling' mean in the context of evapotranspiration data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of evapotranspiration data collection, 'upscaling' refers to the process of adjusting in situ observations to match the spatial scale of remotely sensed data. It involves using various methods to extend ground truth ET data to the satellite pixel scale, addressing the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remotely sensed ET products.

Definition.Question: What does 'flux observation matrix' entail in the context of eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: In eco-hydrological research, a 'flux observation matrix' typically includes a network of instruments like eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. These tools are used to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes and provide comprehensive data for understanding interactions between different landscape elements, such as in the HiWATER experiment.

Comparison.Question: How does the performance of area-weighted upscaling methods for estimating evapotranspiration compare to the random forest method over heterogeneous surfaces in the Heihe River Basin?
Comparison.Answer: The area-weighted method performed better than other methods over homogeneous surfaces, whereas the random forest method performed better over highly heterogeneous underlying surfaces in the Heihe River Basin.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection techniques used during the intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations in the HiWATER experiment?
Comparison.Answer: The intensive observation periods (IOPs) involved a focused collection of data using instruments arranged in hierarchically nested scales, capturing eco-hydrological processes through instruments like LiDAR and multi-angle thermal imagers. Continuous hydrometeorological observations involved ongoing data gathering using a sparse network of instruments such as EC towers and automatic meteorological stations.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential benefits and challenges of using multiple upscaling methods for estimating evapotranspiration at a satellite pixel scale?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of multiple upscaling methods can provide flexibility and potentially increase the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates by selecting the most appropriate method based on the heterogeneity of the underlying surface. However, challenges include the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remotely sensed data, as well as the varying applicability and pros and cons of each method, which can affect the validation and accuracy of the estimates.

Interpretation.Question: How does the heterogeneity of the underlying surface influence the choice of data collection methods and the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The heterogeneity of the underlying surface significantly influences which data collection methods are used and the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements. For homogeneous surfaces, simpler methods like area-weighted upscaling may suffice, whereas more complex methods such as weighted area-to-area regression kriging or random forest may be needed for moderately to highly heterogeneous surfaces. This variability impacts the effectiveness of the measurement and the level of uncertainty in the results.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes of spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remotely sensed evapotranspiration data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial-scale mismatch arises because in situ measurements are often taken at a fine scale, while remotely sensed data cover larger areas, leading to discrepancies. Additionally, the heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces and the complexity of near-surface meteorological conditions further exacerbate this mismatch, impacting validation results.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to select appropriate validation pixels when dealing with evapotranspiration data from heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Selecting appropriate validation pixels is crucial because the spatial-scale mismatch can be partially addressed by choosing pixels that accurately represent the variability within the area. This helps to reduce uncertainty and improve the reliability of the validation process, especially in heterogeneous surfaces where subpixel variations can significantly affect results.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in determining the most appropriate upscaling method for obtaining ground truth evapotranspiration data at the satellite pixel scale?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in selecting the best upscaling method is due to the heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces and the varying complexity of near-surface meteorological conditions. Each upscaling method has its strengths and weaknesses, and their applicability can differ widely depending on these factors, making it challenging to identify a universally optimal approach.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ observations and remotely sensed data affect the accuracy of evapotranspiration models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The spatial-scale mismatch can introduce uncertainties in the validation process of evapotranspiration models, as it affects the ability to accurately capture the heterogeneity of the underlying surface, leading to potential inaccuracies in model outputs.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can be achieved by applying different upscaling methods over heterogeneous surfaces for evapotranspiration data validation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying different upscaling methods over heterogeneous surfaces can lead to varying levels of accuracy in evapotranspiration data validation, with methods like area-weighted techniques performing better over homogeneous surfaces, while methods such as weighted area-to-area regression kriging and random forest perform better over moderately and highly heterogeneous surfaces respectively.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives of employing multiscale observation systems like HiWATER for data collection in oasis-desert environments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives of employing multiscale observation systems like HiWATER are to capture the complex, multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert environments. This involves using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to gather diverse and comprehensive data that address the challenges posed by the heterogeneity of the surface and the availability of multiscale observations, ultimately aiding in the investigation of oasis-desert interactions and improving the understanding of these systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why might it be necessary to perform a comparative study of various upscaling methods for evapotranspiration data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A comparative study of various upscaling methods is necessary because the heterogeneity of underlying surfaces and the complexity of near-surface meteorological conditions can affect the applicability and effectiveness of different upscaling methods. By evaluating the pros and cons of each method, researchers can determine the most suitable approach for reducing uncertainty due to spatial-scale mismatch and acquiring accurate evapotranspiration data at the satellite pixel scale over heterogeneous landscapes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multi-scale eco-hydrological processes observed and recorded in the Heihe River Basin using remote sensing and ground instruments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the Heihe River Basin, multi-scale eco-hydrological processes are observed using a combination of flux observation matrices, including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additionally, a sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index, as well as hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, is utilized. Synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes are also part of the data collection method.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are used to address the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ observations and remote-sensed evapotranspiration data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address the spatial-scale mismatch, several upscaling methods are used, such as the area-weighted method, integrated Priestley-Taylor equation, weighted area-to-area regression kriging, artificial neural network, random forest, and deep belief network methods. These methods are compared via direct validation and cross-validation to determine their applicability over heterogeneous surfaces and to acquire ground truth evapotranspiration data at the satellite pixel scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the quality control of observational data collected during the HiWATER experiment in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The quality control of observational data collected during the HiWATER experiment is ensured through careful processes that include sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This meticulous approach is applied to the various instruments and methodologies used in the experiment to maintain the integrity and reliability of the data.

Enablement.Question: What observational techniques and instrumentation are necessary to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including flux observation matrices of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, are necessary to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces.

Enablement.Question: How do different upscaling methods enable the acquisition of ground truth evapotranspiration data at the satellite pixel scale over heterogeneous surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Different upscaling methods such as area-weighted method, integrated Priestley-Taylor equation, weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATARK), artificial neural networks, random forest, and deep belief network methods enable the acquisition of ground truth evapotranspiration data at the satellite pixel scale by addressing the spatial-scale mismatch and considering the heterogeneity of underlying surfaces.

Enablement.Question: What are the necessary conditions for selecting appropriate validation pixels to address the spatial-scale mismatch in remotely sensed evapotranspiration products?
Enablement.Answer: It is necessary to select validation pixels that account for the spatial-scale mismatch between in situ measurements and remotely sensed evapotranspiration products. The heterogeneity of the subpixel must be considered, as it can significantly impact the validation results.
